name: Weijun Zhang
label: Ph.D. Candidate
summary: Ph.D. Candidate in Mechanical and Aerospace Engineering at UC Davis, specializing in intelligent metal additive and hybrid manufacturing. My research focuses on real-time sensing, multi-sensor data fusion, and adaptive closed-loop process control for Directed Energy Deposition (DED) processes. I aim to advance Industry 5.0 concepts by creating autonomous, geometry-aware, and human-centered manufacturing ecosystems.

work_experience.summary: Conducting advanced research in intelligent metal additive and hybrid manufacturing, with focus on real-time process control and monitoring systems for Directed Energy Deposition (DED).
highlights: Developed first-of-its-kind comprehensive real-time monitoring and control system for DED processes
Designed dual-loop hybrid controllers achieving 56% reduction in build height variability and 50% improvement in width uniformity
Reduced cycle time by over 25% while maintaining geometric accuracy and improving thermal management
Published 6 journal articles with 4+ manuscripts in preparation/under review

work_experience.summary: Contributed to data-driven mechanical sensing and input system development for Mac products through mechanical design and physics-informed machine learning modeling.
highlights: Developed sensing solutions that improved interaction localization accuracy from 83% to 97%
Performed DOE to identify root causes of performance variation and implement corrective design actions
Designed components in Siemens NX, conducted FEA in ABAQUS, and collaborated with cross-functional teams
Fabricated functional prototypes using metal additive manufacturing, wire EDM, and multi-axis CNC machining

work_experience.summary: Instructed 140+ undergraduates in ABET-accredited courses covering engineering graphics and manufacturing processes.
highlights: Delivered ABET-aligned lectures 2-3 times per week for ENG 004 and EME 050 courses
Integrated research topics including metal 3D printing, process planning, and metrology into curriculum
Supervised 10 teaching assistants supporting studio instruction and machine tool demonstrations
Earned student evaluations exceeding 90% satisfaction

work_experience.summary: Led hands-on lab sessions for 300+ undergraduates in ABET-accredited courses including engineering graphics, measurement systems, manufacturing processes, mechatronics, and advanced manufacturing.
highlights: Taught CAD (SOLIDWORKS), CNC machining (Clausing lathe, Bridgeport mill, DMG MORI DMU50 with Fusion 360 CAM)
Instructed LabVIEW circuits/sensors and mechatronics projects with PID control systems
Designed graduate-level manufacturing demos (high-speed CNC machining, chatter vibration analysis)
Consistently received over 90% satisfaction in student and faculty evaluations

projects.title: Comprehensive DED Control System
projects.summary: Developed a first-of-its-kind comprehensive, real-time monitoring and control system for Directed Energy Deposition processes, forming the core of Ph.D. dissertation research (2022-Present).
highlights: Designed dual-loop hybrid controllers manipulating laser power, deposition feed rate, and powder flow rate for multi-objective control
Reduced build height variability by 56% and improved width uniformity by 50%
Cut cycle time by over 25% while maintaining geometric accuracy
Validated on two different laser head systems with improved residual stress outcomes
Contributed to 4 journal publications

projects.title: Material Property Analysis of DED Thin-Walls
projects.summary: Multi-institutional collaboration (UC Davis, J-PARC, KIT) analyzing material properties and residual stress in DED-manufactured thin-wall specimens (2023-Present).
highlights: Measured internal residual stress using neutron diffractometer
Analyzed porosity, grain size, hardness, and tensile strength of 316L specimens
Demonstrated that energy-based control reduced residual stress
Showed powder-based control induced beneficial compressive stress
Established foundation for material-aware adaptive control

projects.title: Comparative Study of Hybrid Additive-Subtractive Processes
projects.summary: Multi-institutional benchmarking study (UC Davis, UW-Madison, TU Wien) comparing three hybrid manufacturing processes: DED powder, WAAM wire, and friction surfacing (2024-2025).
highlights: Fabricated identical artifact geometries using three different hybrid processes
Assessed geometric accuracy, material behavior, and system integration differences
Analyzed cycle time, resource consumption, distortion, energy consumption, microstructure, and mechanical properties
Friction Surfacing demonstrated higher hardness due to solid-state nature
WAAM offered lower cycle times and resource consumption; DED provided near net shape geometries

Oversaw lab budgeting and logistics

volunteer_experience.summary: Mentoring undergraduate students in research, machining, and career development.

Supported graduate school and scholarship applications
Mentored visiting international Ph.D. scholar, resulting in co-authored publication

volunteer_experience.summary: Contributing to peer review and conference organization for major manufacturing conferences.
